name: Li Chen
quote: A recipe has no soul. You, as the cook, must bring soul to the recipe.

recipes.name: Kung Pao Chicken
ingredients: 1 lb chicken breast, cut into small cubes
instructions: Marinate the chicken in cornstarch, soy sauce, and Shaoxing wine for 15-20 minutes.
Heat the oil in a wok over high heat. Add the chicken and stir-fry until browned and cooked through, about 5-6 minutes.
Add the garlic, ginger, dried chilies, and Sichuan peppercorns. Stir-fry for another minute.
Add the green onions and roasted peanuts. Stir-fry for 1-2 minutes.
Remove from heat and serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Dan Dan Noodles
instructions: Cook the noodles according to package instructions and set aside.
Heat a wok over high heat. Add the pork and stir-fry until browned and cooked through, about 5-6 minutes.
Add the garlic and ginger and stir-fry for another minute.
Add the chili oil, Sichuan peppercorn oil, light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, and sugar. Stir-fry for another minute.
Add the cooked noodles and toss everything together. Plate the noodles and garnish with chopped scallions and cilantro.

recipes.name: Mapo Tofu
ingredients: 1 lb soft or silken tofu, cut into small cubes
instructions: Mix the cornstarch and water in a small bowl and set aside.
Heat the oil in a wok over high heat. Add the pork and stir-fry until browned and cooked through, about 5-6 minutes.
Add the garlic, ginger, doubanjiang, fermented black beans, and Sichuan peppercorns. Stir-fry for another minute.
Add the tofu and gently stir everything together, being careful not to break up the tofu too much.
Pour in the cornstarch slurry and stir gently to thicken the sauce.
Remove from heat and serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Ma La Tang (Spicy Hot Pot)
instructions: Fill a large pot with water and bring it to aboil over high heat.
In the meantime, prepare all the ingredients and set them aside.
Heat a small saucepan over medium-high heat. Add the vegetable oil and Sichuan peppercorns, and stir-fry until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add the chili oil, Sichuan peppercorn oil, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, and sugar to the saucepan. Stir everything together and remove from heat.
Once the water is boiling, reduce the heat to medium-low. Place all the prepared ingredients on plates and bowls and bring them to the table.
To assemble the hot pot, let each person choose the ingredients they want to cook and add them to the pot. Cook for about 1-2 minutes or until the meat is cooked through.
Remove the cooked ingredients from the pot and dip them in the sauce before eating.
Enjoy your spicy hot pot!

recipes.name: Sichuan Boiled Beef (Shui Zhu Niu Rou)
instructions: Mix the cornstarch and water in a small bowl and set aside.
Heat a wok over high heat. Add the Sichuan peppercorns and dry fry until fragrant, about 1 minute.
Add the chili bean paste, fermented black beans, vegetable oil, garlic, and ginger. Stir-fry for another minute.
Add the beef stock or water and bring to a boil.
Add the beef slices and cook until just cooked through, about 2-3 minutes.
Stir in the cornstarch slurry and cook until the sauce thickens.
Remove from heat and garnish with chopped green onions before serving hot with rice.

recipes.name: Shanghai-style Braised Pork Belly (Hong Shao Rou)
ingredients: 1 lb pork belly, cut into small cubes
1 tbsp rock sugar or granulated sugar
instructions: Add the pork belly to a pot of boiling water and blanch for 5 minutes. Drain and set aside.
In another pot, add the water, Shaoxing wine, dark soy sauce, light soy sauce, rock sugar, ginger, and star anise. Stir everything together and bring to a boil.
Add the blanched pork belly to the pot and bring back to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, for about 60-90 minutes or until the pork belly is tenderand the sauce has thickened.
Remove from heat and garnish with chopped green onions before serving hot with rice.

recipes.name: Scallion Pancakes
instructions: In a mixing bowl, combine flour and salt. Mix well.
Slowly add boiling water to the mixture while stirring continuously until a dough forms.
Knead the dough on a floured surface for about 5 minutes or until smooth.
Divide the dough into 8 equal pieces and roll each piece out into a thin circle.
Brush each circle with vegetable oil and sprinkle with scallions.
Roll up each circle tightly like a jelly roll and then coil it into a snail shape.
Flatten each coiled piece of dough with your palm and then use a rolling pin to roll it out again into a thin pancake.
Heat a skillet over medium-high heat and cook each pancake for about 2-3 minutes on each side or until golden brown and crispy.
Remove from heat and serve hot with soy sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Shanghai-style Fried Rice
instructions: Heat a wok over high heat. Add the vegetable oil and garlic, and stir-fry for 30 seconds.
Add the ham and peas, and stir-fry for another minute.
Push everything to the side of the wok and add in the beaten eggs. Scramble the eggs until they are cooked through.
Add the rice to the wok and stir-fry everything together.
Add the soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, and sugar, and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes or until everything is heated through.
Remove from heat and garnish with chopped green onions before serving hot.

recipes.name: Stir-fried Shanghai Greens (You Cai)
ingredients: 1 lb Shanghai greens (you cai) or baby bok choy, washed and trimmed
instructions: Heat a wok over high heat. Add the vegetable oil and garlic, stir-fry for 30 seconds.
Add the Shanghai greens or baby bok choy to the wok and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes or until just wilted.
Add the oyster sauce, water, sugar, and salt, and continue stir-frying for another minute or until the greens are coated in the sauce and tender.
Remove from heat and serve hot as a side dish.

recipes.name: Xiao Long Bao (Soup Dumplings)
ingredients: 1/2 cup cold chicken stock or water
instructions: Mix the ground pork with the bamboo shoots, shiitake mushrooms, scallions, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sesame oil, sugar, salt, and white pepper in a bowl. Stir everything together well.
Add the chicken stock or water and stir until it is completely incorporated into the filling mixture.
Take a dumpling wrapper and place a heaping tablespoon of the filling in the center. Seal the dumpling by folding the edges together to form pleats.
Place the dumplings in a bamboo steamer and steam over high heat for about 8-10 minutes.
Remove from heat and serve hot with soy sauce or black vinegar for dipping.

recipes.name: Steamed Fish with Ginger and Scallions
ingredients: 1 whole fish, cleaned and scaled (e.g., sea bass or red snapper)
instructions: Place the whole fish on a heat-proof plate that will fit inside a steamer basket.
Scatter the minced garlic, ginger, and sliced scallions all over the top of the fish.
In a small bowl, mix together soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sugar, and water. Pour this mixture over the fish.
Fill a wok or large pot with about 1-2 inches of water and bring it to a boil over high heat.
Place the plate with the fish in the steamer basket and carefully lower it into the wok or pot.
Cover the steamer basket with a lid and steam the fish for about 10-15 minutes or until cooked through.
Remove the steamer basket from the wok or pot and carefully remove the lid. Use a spoon to remove any excess water that may have collected on top of the fish.
Heat the vegetable oil in a small saucepan over high heat. Once hot, pour the oil over the fish.
Garnish with additional sliced scallions before serving hot with rice.

recipes.name: Cantonese-style Lobster
ingredients: 2 live lobsters (about 1 1/2 lbs each), cleaned and halved
instructions: Preheat the broiler on high.
In a mixing bowl, combine Shaoxing wine, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar. Mix well.
Place the lobster halves on a baking sheet, flesh side up, and brush them generously with the sauce mixture.
Broil the lobster halves in the preheated oven for about 8-10 minutes or until the shells are red and the meat is cooked through.
Meanwhile, heat the vegetable oil in a small saucepan over high heat. Once hot, add the minced garlic, ginger, and sliced scallions. Stir-fry for about 1 minute or until fragrant.
Remove the lobster halves from the broiler and transfer them to a large platter. Pour the stir-fried garlic, ginger, and scallion mixture over the top of the lobster halves.
Serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Wok-fried Clams with Black Bean Sauce
ingredients: 2 tbsp fermented black beans, rinsed and mashed with a fork
instructions: Heat a wok over high heat. Add the vegetable oil and swirl it around to coat the wok.
Add the minced garlic, ginger, and sliced scallions to the wok and stir-fry for about 30 seconds or until fragrant.
Add the mashed fermented black beans to the wok and stir-fry for another 30 seconds.
Add the cleaned Manila clams to the wok and stir-fry everything together.
Add the soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sugar, and water to the wok. Mix everything together and cover the wok with a lid.
Cook for about 5-7 minutes or until all the clams have opened up.
Remove from heat and discard any clams that did not open. Garnish with additional sliced scallions before serving hot with rice.

recipes.name: Cantonese-style Steamed Spare Ribs with Black Bean Sauce
ingredients: 1 tbsp fermented black beans, rinsed and mashed with a fork
instructions: Cut the pork spare ribs into bite-sized pieces and place them in a heat-proof plate that will fit inside a steamer basket.
In a mixing bowl, combine mashed fermented black beans, minced garlic, julienned ginger, sliced scallions, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine, sugar, and water. Mix well.
Pour this mixture over the pork spare ribs, making sure they are evenly coated.

Place the plate with the pork spare ribs in the steamer basket and carefully lower it into the wok or pot.

Remove the steamer basket from the wok or pot and carefully remove the lid. Use a spoon to remove any excess water that may have collected on top of the pork spare ribs.
